items.title: Trump turns fire on Putin and lauds UK in press conference with Starmer
items.standfirst: US president also advises PM to use military to stop irregular migration at conclusion of his second state visit Donald Trump has accused Vladimir Putin of letting him down in a joint press conference with Keir Starmer during which the US president piled criticism on his Russian counterpart.Trump said on Thursday that he had hoped to broker a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine soon after entering office, but that Putin’s actions had prevented him from doing so. Continue reading...

items.title: UK preparing to recognise Palestinian state as early as Friday
items.standfirst: Move comes after Israel fails to meet UK conditions that would have postponed stepThe UK is preparing to recognise the state of Palestine as early as Friday, after Israel failed to meet conditions that would have postponed the historic step, including a ceasefire in Gaza.Keir Starmer insisted the timing of the UK announcement had nothing to do with Donald Trump’s visit, even though the US president said at a press conference that he disagreed with Britain’s decision, without elaborating. Continue reading...
items.content: Move comes after Israel fails to meet UK conditions that would have postponed stepThe UK is preparing to recognise the state of Palestine as early as Friday, after Israel failed to meet conditions that would have postponed the historic step, including a ceasefire in Gaza.Keir Starmer insisted the timing of the UK announcement had nothing to do with Donald Trump’s visit, even though the US president said at a press conference that he disagreed with Britain’s decision, without elaborating. items.title: Trump says he wants Bagram air base in Afghanistan back from Taliban
items.standfirst: President Trump said he is trying to get the Bagram air base in Afghanistan "back" during his press conference with British Prime Minister Keir Starmer. Jonathan Wachtel, a global affairs analyst and OurCo co-founder, joins CBS News to discuss the announcement's significance.

items.title: Donald Trump, Keir Starmer and their vision on ongoing conflicts
items.standfirst: During a joint press conference, US President Donald Trump and UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer addressed multiple international conflicts. They highlighted differing perspectives on Gaza and Ukraine, with Trump openly disagreeing with Russian President Vladimir Putin’s actions. The leaders outlined their approaches while acknowledging contrasting views on key global issues. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert has more on the issue.
items.content: During a joint press conference, US President Donald Trump and UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer addressed multiple international conflicts. They highlighted differing perspectives on Gaza and Ukraine, with Trump openly disagreeing with Russian President Vladimir Putin’s actions. The leaders outlined their approaches while acknowledging contrasting views on key global issues. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert has more on the issue.

items.title: Trump Says US Is Close to a TikTok Deal With China
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump says the US is close to making a deal for TikTok with China. Trump says it would be done “in conjunction with China” and that the US is getting “a ‘fee plus’ for just making the deal," He spoke at a press conference alongside British Prime Minister Keir Starmer. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: President Donald Trump says the US is close to making a deal for TikTok with China. Trump says it would be done “in conjunction with China” and that the US is getting “a ‘fee plus’ for just making the deal," He spoke at a press conference alongside British Prime Minister Keir Starmer. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: Kimmel's future hangs in balance after ABC suspends his late-night show over Charlie Kirk comments
Calls grow to boycott ABC owner Disney over Jimmy Kimmel suspension
items.standfirst: Critics say ‘authoritarianism isn’t coming – it’s already here’ amid widespread condemnation of talkshow’s suspensionThe indefinite suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s late-night show has prompted impassioned calls for a boycott against Disney, ABC’s parent company, and other major media conglomerates that have refused to air Kimmel’s show.Boycott calls grew after ABC announced it would indefinitely suspend the popular show following complaints from Federal Communications Commission chairman Brendan Carr. Carr’s complaints stem from Kimmel’s recent monologue in which he addressed the killing of rightwing activist Charlie Kirk by saying: “Many in Maga land are working very hard to capitalize on the murder of Charlie Kirk.” Continue reading...
items.content: Critics say ‘authoritarianism isn’t coming – it’s already here’ amid widespread condemnation of talkshow’s suspensionThe indefinite suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s late-night show has prompted impassioned calls for a boycott against Disney, ABC’s parent company, and other major media conglomerates that have refused to air Kimmel’s show.Boycott calls grew after ABC announced it would indefinitely suspend the popular show following complaints from Federal Communications Commission chairman Brendan Carr. Carr’s complaints stem from Kimmel’s recent monologue in which he addressed the killing of rightwing activist Charlie Kirk by saying: “Many in Maga land are working very hard to capitalize on the murder of Charlie Kirk.” Continue reading...

items.title: ‘Censoring you in real time’: suspension of Jimmy Kimmel show sparks shock and fears for free speech
items.standfirst: ABC decision over Kimmel comments comes hours after Trump-appointed chair of US media regulator threatened broadcaster’s affiliate stations’ licensesWhat did Jimmy Kimmel say about Charlie Kirk?Jimmy Kimmel show suspended – live updatesPoliticians, media figures and free speech organisations continued to express anger and alarm at the suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s late-night show, warning that critics of Donald Trump were being systematically silenced.ABC announced it was suspending Jimmy Kimmel Live! indefinitely after comments Kimmel made about Charlie Kirk’s killing led a group of ABC-affiliated stations to say it would not air the show. Continue reading...
items.content: ABC decision over Kimmel comments comes hours after Trump-appointed chair of US media regulator threatened broadcaster’s affiliate stations’ licensesWhat did Jimmy Kimmel say about Charlie Kirk?Jimmy Kimmel show suspended – live updatesPoliticians, media figures and free speech organisations continued to express anger and alarm at the suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s late-night show, warning that critics of Donald Trump were being systematically silenced.ABC announced it was suspending Jimmy Kimmel Live! indefinitely after comments Kimmel made about Charlie Kirk’s killing led a group of ABC-affiliated stations to say it would not air the show. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump comments on Jimmy Kimmel being pulled off air

items.content: President Trump on Thursday addressed ABC's decision to pre-empt "Jimmy Kimmel Live!" over comments Kimmel made about the shooting of Charlie Kirk. CBS News correspondent Shanelle Kaul has more.

items.title: ‘Court of King Trump’: how media barons are bowing to president to protect key deals
items.standfirst: Suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s TV show over Charlie Kirk comments is latest sign of business coming under pressure from White HouseThe indefinite suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s 22-year run on late-night TV is the latest sign of the pressure US media businesses are under to bend to the rightwing views endorsed by Donald Trump, or face commercial cancellation.The decision by the Disney-owned ABC followed Kimmel’s on-air accusations that the Republicans were doing everything they could to score political points from the killing of Charlie Kirk. It came after one of the biggest owners of TV stations in the US, Nexstar, had said it would replace Kimmel’s show for the foreseeable future. Continue reading...
items.content: Suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s TV show over Charlie Kirk comments is latest sign of business coming under pressure from White HouseThe indefinite suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s 22-year run on late-night TV is the latest sign of the pressure US media businesses are under to bend to the rightwing views endorsed by Donald Trump, or face commercial cancellation.The decision by the Disney-owned ABC followed Kimmel’s on-air accusations that the Republicans were doing everything they could to score political points from the killing of Charlie Kirk. It came after one of the biggest owners of TV stations in the US, Nexstar, had said it would replace Kimmel’s show for the foreseeable future. Continue reading...

The suspension sparked political attention, with President Donald Trump praising the decision and framing it as a victory against media bias.

items.title: Immigration judge rules Mahmoud Khalil should be deported
items.standfirst: An immigration judge in Louisiana has ruled that Palestinian activist Mahmoud Khalil can be deported for not disclosing information on his green card application.
items.content: An immigration judge in Louisiana has ruled that Palestinian activist Mahmoud Khalil can be deported for not disclosing information on his green card application.

items.title: Judge orders Columbia activist Mahmoud Khalil to be deported to Algeria or Syria
items.standfirst: A federal immigration judge has ordered Mahmoud Khalil — a former Columbia University graduate student linked to pro-Palestinian protests — to be deported.
items.content: A federal immigration judge has ordered Mahmoud Khalil — a former Columbia University graduate student linked to pro-Palestinian protests — to be deported.

items.title: US immigration judge orders expulsion of pro-Palestinian student Mahmoud Khalil
items.standfirst: A US judge orders the deportation of Mahmoud Khalil, a pro-Palestinian activist and legal US resident. Khalil gained national attention during protests at Columbia University last year, spending over 100 days in jail. Solange Mougin reports on the case.
items.content: A US judge orders the deportation of Mahmoud Khalil, a pro-Palestinian activist and legal US resident. Khalil gained national attention during protests at Columbia University last year, spending over 100 days in jail. Solange Mougin reports on the case.

items.title: US judge orders deportation of Palestinian activist Mahmoud Khalil
items.standfirst: An immigration judge ordered Khalil be deported to Algeria or Syria over claims he omitted information on a green card application.
items.content: An immigration judge ordered Khalil be deported to Algeria or Syria over claims he omitted information on a green card application.

items.title: US judge orders Mahmoud Khalil deported citing ‘misrepresented facts’ on green card form
items.standfirst: Lawyers say pro-Palestinian activist remains protected from immigration enforcement while separate federal court case proceedsAn immigration judge in the US state of Louisiana has ordered the deportation of pro-Palestinian protest leader Mahmoud Khalil to Algeria or Syria, ruling that he failed to disclose information on his green card application, according to court documents filed on Wednesday.Khalil’s lawyers said they intended to appeal against the deportation order, and that a federal district court’s separate orders remain in effect prohibiting the government from immediately deporting or detaining him as his federal court case proceeds. The lawyers submitted a letter to the federal court in New Jersey overseeing his civil rights case and said he will challenge the decision. Continue reading...
items.content: Lawyers say pro-Palestinian activist remains protected from immigration enforcement while separate federal court case proceedsAn immigration judge in the US state of Louisiana has ordered the deportation of pro-Palestinian protest leader Mahmoud Khalil to Algeria or Syria, ruling that he failed to disclose information on his green card application, according to court documents filed on Wednesday.Khalil’s lawyers said they intended to appeal against the deportation order, and that a federal district court’s separate orders remain in effect prohibiting the government from immediately deporting or detaining him as his federal court case proceeds. The lawyers submitted a letter to the federal court in New Jersey overseeing his civil rights case and said he will challenge the decision. Continue reading...

ai_summary: An immigration judge ruled Mahmoud Khalil should be deported.
The judge cited Khalil's failure to disclose information on his green card.
Khalil is a former Columbia University graduate student and activist.
Khalil's lawyers plan to appeal the deportation order.
A separate federal court case protects Khalil from immediate deportation.

items.title: Trump asks Supreme Court to allow Lisa Cook firing
items.standfirst: The Trump administration has asked the Supreme Court to allow the president to fire Lisa Cook from the Federal Reserve Board of Governors. CBS News' Kelly O'Grady reports.
items.content: The Trump administration has asked the Supreme Court to allow the president to fire Lisa Cook from the Federal Reserve Board of Governors. CBS News' Kelly O'Grady reports.

items.title: Trump administration asks supreme court to allow firing of Fed’s Lisa Cook
items.standfirst: Request sets stage for historic test of presidential power as Trump pursues greater control of the Federal ReserveThe Trump administration asked the US supreme court to allow it to fire the Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook, as it continues its extraordinary attack on the central bank’s independence.In a filing on Thursday, Donald Trump’s officials requested an emergency order to remove Cook from the Fed’s board of governors, after an appeals court refused to go along with efforts to oust her. Continue reading...
items.content: Request sets stage for historic test of presidential power as Trump pursues greater control of the Federal ReserveThe Trump administration asked the US supreme court to allow it to fire the Federal Reserve governor Lisa Cook, as it continues its extraordinary attack on the central bank’s independence.In a filing on Thursday, Donald Trump’s officials requested an emergency order to remove Cook from the Fed’s board of governors, after an appeals court refused to go along with efforts to oust her. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Trump administration requested an emergency order from the Supreme Court.
The request aims to remove Lisa Cook from the Federal Reserve board.
This follows an appeals court's refusal to remove Cook.
The case could set a precedent on the Fed's independence.
The administration is seeking greater control of the Federal Reserve.

items.title: Erika Kirk named CEO of Turning Point USA after her husband's assassination
items.standfirst: Erika Kirk has been named CEO of Turning Point USA, the conservative youth organization founded by her husband, Charlie Kirk, until his assassination.
items.content: Erika Kirk has been named CEO of Turning Point USA, the conservative youth organization founded by her husband, Charlie Kirk, until his assassination.

items.title: Erika Kirk, widow of Charlie Kirk, to helm TPUSA
items.standfirst: Kirk will take over one of the most influential conservative organizing groups from her late husband.
items.content: The board of conservative youth organization Turning Point USA voted unanimously to hand over the reins of the group to Erika Kirk, widow of political activist Charlie Kirk. In a statement, the group said Thursday that Charlie Kirk had expressed to executives that he wished for his wife to take over as chief executive and board chair in the event of his death. “We will not surrender or kneel before evil,” the group’s board members wrote. “We will carry on. The attempt to destroy Charlie’s work will become our chance to make it more powerful and enduring than ever before.” Erika Kirk, a graduate of Liberty University, won the Miss Arizona USA pageant in 2012 and went on to start her own podcast, clothing brand and nonprofit organization, and married the political organizer in 2021. Charlie Kirk cofounded TPUSA in 2012. She is set to speak at a memorial for her deceased husband at State Farm Stadium in Glendale, Arizona — home to the Arizona Cardinals football team — alongside President Donald Trump, Vice President JD Vance and several senior administration officials. The influential political organization has seen a surge in interest from young conservatives since the fatal shooting of its leader last week at a university in Utah. In the week following Charlie Kirk’s killing, the group said it had received more than 50,000 requests from high school and college students to start a chapter with the organization’s network or join an existing one. Erika Kirk vowed to carry on her husband’s legacy in the wake of his death, committing to “make Turning Point the biggest thing this nation has ever seen” in public remarks just hours after authorities announced the arrest of Tyler Robinson, a 22-year-old Utah man now charged with aggravated murder. Republicans intend to elevate Charlie Kirk’s killing as they look to the 2026 midterm elections, highlighting what they call radical left-wing violence and aiming to carry on his legacy of mobilizing young voters to turn out for Republicans.

ai_summary: Erika Kirk, Charlie Kirk's widow, is now CEO of Turning Point USA.
She will also serve as chair of the board.
Turning Point USA is a conservative youth organization.
The organization was founded by her late husband, Charlie Kirk.
Kirk takes over one of the most influential conservative groups.

items.title: US Federal Reserve cuts interest rates for first time in nine months
items.standfirst: The US Federal Reserve has lowered interest rates by a quarter percentage point, bringing its benchmark rate to a range of 4.00 to 4.25 percent. All but one of the 12 members of the monetary policy committee voted in favor of the decision, with the sole dissent coming from newly appointed governor Stephen Miran, a trusted ally of President Trump. And, Jerry Greenfield, co-founder of Ben & Jerry’s, has quit the company, accusing its parent firm, Unilever, of silencing the brand’s social activism.
items.content: The US Federal Reserve has lowered interest rates by a quarter percentage point, bringing its benchmark rate to a range of 4.00 to 4.25 percent. All but one of the 12 members of the monetary policy committee voted in favor of the decision, with the sole dissent coming from newly appointed governor Stephen Miran, a trusted ally of President Trump. And, Jerry Greenfield, co-founder of Ben & Jerry’s, has quit the company, accusing its parent firm, Unilever, of silencing the brand’s social activism.

items.title: Ben & Jerry’s co-founder quits, accusing Unilever of silencing social mission
items.standfirst: Jerry Greenfield says he cannot ‘in good conscience’ continue and says company has lost its independenceThe Ben & Jerry’s co-founder Jerry Greenfield has stepped away from the ice-cream brand after nearly 50 years, claiming it has lost its independence and accusing its parent company, Unilever, of having “silenced” its social mission.Greenfield said in a letter posted by his co-founder, Ben Cohen, that he could no longer “in good conscience” remain an employee of a business that he argued had been muzzled by the UK-listed Unilever, despite an agreement protecting its social mission when it was taken over in 2000. Continue reading...
items.content: Jerry Greenfield says he cannot ‘in good conscience’ continue and says company has lost its independenceThe Ben & Jerry’s co-founder Jerry Greenfield has stepped away from the ice-cream brand after nearly 50 years, claiming it has lost its independence and accusing its parent company, Unilever, of having “silenced” its social mission.Greenfield said in a letter posted by his co-founder, Ben Cohen, that he could no longer “in good conscience” remain an employee of a business that he argued had been muzzled by the UK-listed Unilever, despite an agreement protecting its social mission when it was taken over in 2000. Continue reading...

items.title: Macrons to submit scientific evidence to US court to prove Brigitte was not born a man
items.standfirst: French president and wife allege rightwing influencer Candace Owens is using defamatory attacks against them to boost media profileThe French president, Emmanuel Macron, and his wife plan to present scientific evidence to a US court to prove that Brigitte Macron was not born a man, the lawyer representing them in a defamation suit has said.The couple filed the suit in July against Candace Owens, a rightwing influencer, and her business, alleging continuing defamatory attacks against them in order to boost the profile of her media platform, gain more audience and make money. Continue reading...
items.content: French president and wife allege rightwing influencer Candace Owens is using defamatory attacks against them to boost media profileThe French president, Emmanuel Macron, and his wife plan to present scientific evidence to a US court to prove that Brigitte Macron was not born a man, the lawyer representing them in a defamation suit has said.The couple filed the suit in July against Candace Owens, a rightwing influencer, and her business, alleging continuing defamatory attacks against them in order to boost the profile of her media platform, gain more audience and make money. Continue reading...

items.title: Macrons to offer 'scientific evidence' to US court to prove Brigitte is a woman, lawyer says
items.standfirst: They have filed a lawsuit against US right-wing influencer Candace Owens who claims the French first lady was born male.
items.content: They have filed a lawsuit against US right-wing influencer Candace Owens who claims the French first lady was born male.

ai_summary: The Macrons plan to present scientific evidence in a US court.
They aim to prove Brigitte Macron was not born a man.
The lawsuit is against Candace Owens for defamation.
Owens allegedly made claims to boost her media profile.

clusters.title: Gaza could be 'real estate bonanza', Israeli minister says
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli minister discusses Gaza as real estate

items.title: Gaza could be 'real estate bonanza', Israeli minister says
items.standfirst: A controversial Israeli minister has said Gaza could be a "real estate bonanza" - and that a business plan for redeveloping it had been sent to the US president.
items.content: A controversial Israeli minister has said Gaza could be a "real estate bonanza" - and that a business plan for redeveloping it had been sent to the US president.

items.title: Senior Israeli minister describes plans to turn Gaza into a 'real estate bonanza'
items.standfirst: Israeli Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich said Wednesday that the destruction in the Gaza Strip could be turned into a lucrative real estate opportunity.
items.content: Israeli Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich said Wednesday that the destruction in the Gaza Strip could be turned into a lucrative real estate opportunity.

items.title: Israel's finance minister talks of 'real estate bonanza' in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel’s Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich said a business plan for developing Gaza was on President Trump’s desk, adding, “We've done the demolition phase, which is always the first phase of urban renewal."
items.content: Israel’s Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich said a business plan for developing Gaza was on President Trump’s desk, adding, “We've done the demolition phase, which is always the first phase of urban renewal."

ai_summary: An Israeli minister said Gaza could be a "real estate bonanza".
A business plan for Gaza's redevelopment was sent to the US president.
The minister is Bezalel Smotrich, the Finance Minister.
He stated the demolition phase is complete.

clusters.title: The Indian state fighting rise in cases of rare 'brain-eating' disease
clusters.neutral_headline: Indian state faces rare brain-eating disease

items.title: The Indian state fighting rise in cases of rare 'brain-eating' disease
items.standfirst: Kerala is facing a serious public health challenge as it's seen a surge in cases of a "brain-eating" disease which has caused 19 deaths.
items.content: Kerala is facing a serious public health challenge as it's seen a surge in cases of a "brain-eating" disease which has caused 19 deaths.

items.title: Battling a rare brain-eating disease in an Indian state
items.standfirst: In Kerala this year, more than 70 people have been diagnosed and 19 have died from the brain-eating amoeba.
items.content: In Kerala this year, more than 70 people have been diagnosed and 19 have died from the brain-eating amoeba.

ai_summary: Kerala, India, is facing a rise in cases of a rare brain-eating disease.
Over 70 people have been diagnosed with the disease this year.
Nineteen deaths have been attributed to the disease.

clusters.title: Tests show Navalny was poisoned in jail, his widow says
clusters.neutral_headline: Tests show Navalny was poisoned in jail, his widow says

items.title: Tests show Navalny was poisoned in jail, his widow says
items.standfirst: Yulia Navalnaya is urging the two laboratories she says found her husband was poisoned to release their findings.
items.content: Yulia Navalnaya is urging the two laboratories she says found her husband was poisoned to release their findings.

items.title: Lab tests show Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned, his wife says
items.standfirst: Tests by two foreign laboratories show that Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned before he died in an Arctic penal colony last year, his wife said Wednesday
items.content: Tests by two foreign laboratories show that Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned before he died in an Arctic penal colony last year, his wife said Wednesday

ai_summary: Yulia Navalnaya says tests show Alexei Navalny was poisoned.
Two foreign laboratories conducted the tests.
Navalny died in an Arctic penal colony last year.
She is urging the labs to release their findings.

clusters.title: Hundreds of Machu Picchu tourists stranded
clusters.neutral_headline: Hundreds of Machu Picchu tourists stranded

items.title: Hundreds of Machu Picchu tourists stranded
items.standfirst: Hundreds of tourists have been left stranded near Peru's ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu after rail services were suspended because protesters blocked the route with rocks.
items.content: Hundreds of tourists have been left stranded near Peru's ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu after rail services were suspended because protesters blocked the route with rocks.

items.title: Rocks on train tracks strand 900 Machu Picchu tourists amid protest
items.standfirst: About 1,400 visitors were evacuated but hundreds were left stuck because of action linked to bus contract dispute, say Peru authoritiesAt least 900 tourists were stranded near the ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu on Tuesday, Peru’s tourism minister said, after a passenger train service was suspended due to a protest.PeruRail said service was suspended on Monday because the route in Peru’s mountainous Cusco region had been blocked by “rocks of various sizes” as residents clashed with authorities and bus companies. PeruRail’s local unit also said “third parties” had excavated part of its rail route, which affected the track’s stability and slowed down the evacuation of tourists. Continue reading...
items.content: About 1,400 visitors were evacuated but hundreds were left stuck because of action linked to bus contract dispute, say Peru authoritiesAt least 900 tourists were stranded near the ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu on Tuesday, Peru’s tourism minister said, after a passenger train service was suspended due to a protest.PeruRail said service was suspended on Monday because the route in Peru’s mountainous Cusco region had been blocked by “rocks of various sizes” as residents clashed with authorities and bus companies. PeruRail’s local unit also said “third parties” had excavated part of its rail route, which affected the track’s stability and slowed down the evacuation of tourists. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Hundreds of tourists are stranded near Machu Picchu.
Rail services were suspended due to protests.
Protesters blocked the route with rocks.
Approximately 900 tourists were stranded.
About 1,400 visitors were evacuated.
